I slammed Charon into Pluto, along with a couple more Kuiper objects to make it bigger.

Then Earth.

Then I put it up against Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune.
Pluto won every time, growing ever bigger.
Something odd happened when I slammed it into Jupiter, though. The two bodies started to orbit each other very quickly, Jupiter slowly getting torn apart into little fragments, orbiting Pluto.
Then, Pluto ate all of the fragments.
But it didn't stop there.
Pluto, even though it was leauges smaller than the sun, flew directly toward it.
Upon impact, the sun exploded, creating a massive nebula. At the center of it was Pluto, unharmed.
I kept slamming it into suns.
Eventually, I slammed it into VY Canis Majoris.
Then, lag.
When the lag ended, I zoomed back into Pluto, still alive. But something was different.
Instead of a supermassive planet/star thing, there was a small glowing dot.
Was it a black hole? I don't know.
It was no larger than the sun, and glowing a pleasant red glow, but distorted light near it like a black hole.
I saved it, and put it into a stock solar system.
It immediately ate the sun, and sent every other body flying out into interstellar space at 10000 km/s.

I dubbed this cataclysmic object Pluto Nova.



10/10 would make Pluto destroy the universe again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction
Universe Sandbox ² is a physics-based simulator from eight person team, Giant Army. Universe Sandbox ² is, as you’d expect, a sandbox simulation and therefore you can do pretty much whatever you want within the game’s limitations. Would you like to see what happens to our Solar System when the force of gravity is doubled? You can do that! Want to know what Earth would look like after the moon collided with it? You can find out!

Full Disclosure: A review copy was provided by the developer.

Presentation
Universe Sandbox ² is a good looking simulator. While the textures aren’t great if you zoom in right up to them they do generally look good. The models are all high quality and the visual effects in the game are absolutely brilliant. The developers have done a good job at making the game look as realistic as possible without making it too PC power hungry. As well as looking pretty the game’s appearance is functional. The UI is fairly basic and it doesn’t stick out like a sore thumb but it manages to give the user all the information and options needed to enjoy the simulator. You’ve also got the option to have visible orbits, trails, labels etc. which when on give the user a lot of information but when off allow for some great screenshots to be taken.

Gameplay
I’m not sure gameplay is really the right word for Universe Sandbox ² but I’ll run with it anyway. It’s quite difficult to talk about Universe Sandbox ²’s gameplay as it’s very much what you make of it. For example, if you spend all of your time creating functioning solar systems you’re going to have a rather different experience to someone who mindlessly smashes planets into each other. Those two cover one of the main ways to enjoy the simulation, creating your own scenarios. You’re given access to all of the objects in the game and you can manipulate them however you want to. As well as choosing where to place them relative to other celestial bodies you’re also given a great deal of customisation options for each celestial body such as what materials make up most of its mass or how much mass the celestial body actually has. You can also change what kind of climate planets have through the same menu as the other options or by simply moving the celestial bodies closer or further away from other bodies which have an influence on them.

The other way to enjoy Universe Sandbox ² is to simply run the scenarios which the simulator comes with such as an accurate model of our solar system or a collision between two versions of Jupiter! This is really for those, like myself, who just enjoy watching that kind of thing and of course like watching planets smash into each other. I mean, who wouldn’t enjoy watching two planets smashing into each other? There are already loads of scenarios available in the game and more are being added. Like you can when creating your own scenarios, you’re able to do whatever you want with these scenarios too such as add more planets to your scenario or edit the materials a celestial body is made of.

Miscellaneous You have complete control over how fast the simulation is, you can have each real second represent anything from a millisecond to billions of years.
Universe Sandbox ² has a nice, relaxing soundtrack which fits nicely with calm simulations and contrasts perfectly with huge collisions.
The celestial bodies in the game range from small asteroids to supergiant stars and black holes. There are even some human sized objects in the game including the Monolith from 2001.
The eight person team consists of a numerical physicist, a climate scientist and an astrophysicist as well as ‘regular’ game developers.
While Universe Sandbox ² isn’t too taxing on your GPU you are going to need a pretty beefy CPU to get a good frame rate on some of the more complex simulations.Verdict
Worth Purchasing.

Universe Sandbox ² is a realistic and interesting physics-based sandbox from Giant Army with good graphics and a lot to do. It may not offer much to your average gamer but for those with a real fascination with space it’s a real treat. It may be a bit pricey so for those average gamers I’d suggest holding off for some kind of discount but if you’re a space nut like myself then it’s worth it.

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

Early Access Review

First off I definitely recommend this game, but like all games it has downsides.

This may be a bit of a read, but where is a good review without its detail right?

One of the first things I noticed, when you buy this game that's it, you have the entire game, no special objects I have to buy, if I want to throw a football with the mass of a sun at a teapot the size of our earth, then I can do it as soon as I purchase this game. Which I can tell would appeal to most people.

I'll go over my favourite aspect of the game now, but to save me rambling on about every little feature I enjoy, I'll make a list after this. The thing I love most about this game, is the creativity and curiosity this game brings. As I mentioned before; but who could imagine that you can make a football our solar systems apocalypse?! One things this game does  indeed do very well, is catching the interest and curiosity of people, but also allowing quite a fair bit of creativity.

As I said before I will now make a quick list of all the other things I enjoy a lot about this game:
-Black Holes (you'll spend a lot of your time, if not most of it messing around with black holes).
-Watching what happens when our sun evolves.
-Blowing up every item in the game.
-What happens if's (with the earth especially).
-Trying to make another earth from scratch.
-Turning a teapot into a sun.
-Creating a Solar System.
-Creating a very small galaxy.
-Messing around with the milkyway.
-Making a potential universe descructing object.
-Watching the beautiful simulations, with the beautiful music playing.

Those pretty much cover what I'll be doing and you'll most likely be doing in this game, but the things is, I know there are some more things in the game I haven't started to look at yet, which I will do very soon; they also keep updating this game, so I am always on the look out for any interesting additions they put in.

Alright, so like with every game, it has a few downsides. Here are a few.
After about three hours of playing and testing things out, I started to feel a bit bored and I felt as if I had tried everything that is worth doing (blowing up the earth a million times, and putting a black hole at the centre of our solar system). So what I would say the developers is this, perhaps for a future game, or to just make a big update for this one, think about what more content could you add into this game, or how much more detail can you go into with what happens in space, just to add those extra few hours of interesting gameplay; that being said, I could probably play this for a maximum of two amazing hours, creating my own universe, and creating several apocalyptic situations, then a minimum of a week and a bit, of a break before wanting to play and do that all again. A small suggestion for what you could add; add or make a load more options of what if situations, and perhaps more interesting or ambitious what ifs, like what if aliens were real and invaded our solar system, or what if earth advanced space travel so much they were travelling around our solar system as easy as people can get on a bus now. Maybe too ambitious but you start to see my point.

A final thing, only small, and not the most important downside, but something I certainly picked up upon, and thought, hmm, would have been better with this; is the whole black holes being the most destructive force situation. In this game, all they are, are huge slingshots. Now, I know black holes do something to do with shooting objects out at incredibly high speeds, but I'm no expert. However I also know, or at least have heard from people who are meant to be experts, that under the great force of the gravity a black hole has, objects that are pulled towards it are torn to pieces by the strength of the gravitational pull; and for a lot of people interested in black holes, this is one main thing they focus on; the destructive power it brings wherever it goes. In this game, as I said before, I only see a slingshot, a bunjee jump, to me, a black hole in this game is far from being as deadly and chaotic as they are said to be by experts. I'm almost sure this is to do with the design of the game, that limits this feature, or to do with the time it might have taken to make these extra small details added in; but considering the large majority who will spend most of their time playing around with black holes; I STRONGLY suggest to the developers, that again, either in a very future version of this game, or a large update later on, that there is some sort of design that let's us all see that truly great power a black hole holds, and how merciless it can be.

Those are the two main downsides in this game for me. Although, in conclusion, I certainly recommend this game, it is still fairly new, and having regular updates, (mainly the little fixtures us gamers don't notice very much), but it can give a lot, answer a lot of your curious questions about space, and it is still extremely fun to play. Definitely worth it, and quite frankly, you can never get bored of tossing the moon at earth. Oh, and Developers, if any of you read this, of course, great game, very well done, so congratulations, but also take into account what improvements that I have said could be there in the future.

Thanks!

REPLAYABILITYThe possibilities are truly endless, and as soon as you get the hang of it, you will start modifying all the different planets just to see what happens. Lovers of space simulators will play this for many years to come, also because the developers are constantly updating the game.

I like to think that this is more of an actual software, than it is a game. If you like everything that is related to space, than this is a must-buy. It's a great sequel, and a relaxing game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like astronomy? Do you like space? Do you like smashing two planets together in a fiery explosion? If you answered yes to anything of these questions, then this game is for you! Universe Sandbox 2 is a simulator that lets you experiment on an astronomical level, spawning stars, moons, planets, and pulsars. Create solar sytems (or destroy them), explode stars and watch them go supernova. Its like a star gazing book, except much more fun and interactive. Plus, its real science-y, with accurate data to simulate our own solar system, or a random one... or anything, really. This is a gravity simulator at heart. Orbits, eccentricity, Inclination, velocity, etc. It comes with dozens of pre-made simulations. However, make no mistake, the rest is icing on the cake.

Okay, so now its time for more specificity. Features of the game include stellar evolution, climate simulation, full body fragmentation, light pulses, saving/loading sims, bodies, galaxies (galaxies are WIP for right now), and objects. First is stellar evolution, which is the process of stars aging until they die. You could sit there and watch a star for a billion years in real-time until it dies, or just take the easy route and speed it up.

Next is climate simulation, this works the best with earth for right now. When climate is enabled for a body in the simulation, the polar ice caps (specifically for earth), you can visaully see snow expand and recede as it obits the sun. At some point in the future, climate should become more fleshed out, but for the most part, the climate feature is a nice touch.

I won't go over the whole list, as some are self-explanatory (and there's just too much to list anyway), but the stellar evolution, climate, and light pulses are the main ones, the rest just ties it together, and nicely, I may add. Anyway, light pulses can be pinged" off any object you want in a simulation. Emitting a light pulse from an object will then travel through space. Watching a light pulse in real-time is probably the most amazing. It lets you visualize the speed at which light travels through space. And as far as I know

This is truly an incredible sequel to what is one of the best simulators on Steam! This program feels more like sophisticated simulation software than an actual game in functionality, but it's incredibly user-friendly and easy to use; I use this game as a very effective visual aid for tutoring, as well as a time killer. The developers certainly don't skimp on their research, as frequent updates reflect some of the most current events in astronomy: there was a simulation of the New Horizons encounter with Pluto as the real deal was making headlines! Explorative tutorials are informative without spewing a bunch of numbers and facts all at once; yet they provide links for further enrichment, as well as pure number-crunching horsepower for those who are curious and want to tweak the gritty details and properties that bind the universe together. It's Early Access right now, but their bugs at this point are few and very far between. Updates are very frequent, and more often than not they include newly added features and simulations.

The dynamic graphics for complex events such as climate patterns and planetary collisions are getting better and more refined with each update. This is a sandbox game as the title suggest using physics and fantastic graphics and sound tracks to emulate the universe or your universe.  While many Youtubers will throw moons at planets and call that fun, going much deeper takes a higher level of education. You can build your own solar system from the ground up, drop black holes into anywhere, throw random items into orbit or at planets as well as try to see what happens when you increase the mass of the earth by a couple of suns.  There are no campaigns as this is more of a purely scientific and enjoyable simulation.

The control are simple to learn but the characteristics of the universe contents are vast.  Gravity, mass, density, oribtal configurations, rotational periods, atmosphere, core composition, luminosity, atmosphereic pressure, greenhouse gases, and about 500 other options exist that can be modified.  You can turn on or off realism for each individual object and there are about 50 scenarios you can fire up and watch and/or interact with.

I really enjoy this game..I mean simulation program.  It's relaxing, the sound track makes it easy to study things outside of the game if you are trying to get something done i.e. learn another language, study a new topic in your spare time, etc.  I'm running on a 27 iMac with a 3.4 Ghz i5 with 16 GB of RAM and a 780m Nvidia.  I have no issues playing this game and doing anything I want.  No slowdown

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I really wanted to enjoy this simulation.  But it's severely lacking as is.  Here are my gripes:
#1- Each simulation type is independent of the other.  I was expecting all worlds to have environmental simulations enabled, but they don't.  Only specially designed prefabs (earth and mars I think are only ones?) have the environmental simulation enabled.  There are other simulation setups, but they seem too pigeonholed to really allow for true sandbox tinkering.
#2- It seems like the only interesting things I do are collisions and design some cool orbits I guess.  The level of simulation detail in other areas is far too little to make it fun to me.
#3- Why doesn't the matter projectile thingy add to a planet's makeup and mass?  Atmosphere mechanics are awful.  I was expecting to be able to add gasses or water to a planet and have it establish an atmosphere, or maybe it wasn't big enough to hold an atmosphere?  All cloud cover looks the same as earths, there is no attempt to model a planets atmosphere, and there is absolutely no detail paid to the amazing amount of atmospheric complexity of gas giants.
(these two below are minor gripes)
#4- The simulation including all moons (or even our own moon) is a bit hidden, and I can't find a pre-built simulation including all the defined solar system objects.
#5- Can't you come up with some way to model multiple star systems realistically?  Would be cool if I can hurl one star system at another and see the results  Maybe pause and group multiple stable(ish) objects together as one mass data point at very far zoom distances so that you can actually build a few systems.
#6- The interface needs lots of work.  If I have hundreds of objects on screen, why not (by default) just display the most important trails and orbits at extreme zooms?  Like if I'm looking at the solar system, only the major planets should be shown at max zoom, as I zoom in more, show me smaller and smaller objects or something?  Things get extremely cluttered.  Also, the pause on impact needs a threshold or something and maybe detect an impact a few minutes before it happens so that I can watch or intervene on the things I'm actually interested in.

If you like to watch planets collide for hours with predictable identical results every time, you might get enjoyment out of this.  The only reason I personally didn't ask for return from the dev is that it's a very cool project and I'm hoping I can come back to it in another couple years and it is more the fully featured simulation I was hoping for originally.  Also, the devs care deeply for this game which is great news!

Universe Sandbox is one of the best simulation games I've played. Being able to mess around with the universe or simply create a solar system and see how it turns out in millions of years is great fun and also a learning experience.

I'll be especially excited when the possible simulation of life is added, and I hope that when it happens there will be more options for the planets meant to carry it. I have more to experiment with of course, but I definitely am going to follow this game's development.

I don't dislike much about this game, and for still being in development it's a fantastic start. Anything I could critique about creativity limits will undoubtedly be addressed in the future (Like the creation of life on planets).
I'd recommend this game to anyone who is curious about the universe and how it works. Also for anyone just interested in messing around in space. It is definitely worth getting, and few people aren't interested in outer space, so it seems like a good fit for most.

All in all, it's worth finding out about and looking at. I highly recommend this to anyone I know.

Early Access Review

This game is beautiful, fun, and so well made.
I feel bad for all of the people who wrote reviews saying they got bored with the Universe after only a few hours, it shows an immense lack of creativity.
Yes, you can crash planets into each other, you can blow up the sun, you can crash stars together, and I can see how some people would get bored if that was all they ever did.

Did I do some of those things when I first started playing? Yes, because it's fun and funny.
You want to know what I did after that?
I changed the orbit of Saturn's moons to draw them in closer, causing their orbit trails become bright, colorful rings as they mixed into the debris of Saturn's rings. For good measure I threw Russell's teapot into orbit too
I created a binary solar system from two Sirius B's, with Iapetus and Venus in orbit around one, and Mars and Dione in orbit around the other. I watched a simulated span of 27 days cause Iapetus and Dione to disintegrated and spiral outward into the blackness. I saw emptiness fill up with sparkling lights from the remnants of those moons. I watched Venus begin to heat up till it glowed brighter than the star it was orbiting, and Mars fill with fire leaving glowing streamers in the wake of it's orbit.

There is so much you can do with this game, so many ways to create and destroy, infinite possibilities in the vastness of space, only bound by the limits of your imagination.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Are you a nerd? Do you wonder how things would be different if Mars was closer to the Sun? Or what it would be like if the Earth had two moons? Have you ever wanted to make your own solar system just to see what would happen? Or maybe smash an asteroid into Venus? Or maybe see what happens when you throw a rogue planet into the solar system? You can do these things are more in Universe Sandbox^2.

I found out about this quite game quite accidentally. I had played Space Engine before, and someone mentioned that I should try US^2 if I liked SE. While SE is more of a space-exploration game, US^2 is a sandbox - you can twiddle with settings to see how things change. I guess it's kind of like playing God.

If you had that sense of wonder when you played Space Engine, you can get that here too. You can see how planets change over the scale of centuries and millenia when you mess with their climates. You can change Mars' climate so that it has water. The possibilities are endless.

This is a great learning tool too, especially for children who are interested in astronomy.

Even though it is only in alpha, US^2 is still amazing. If it's so good now, I can't even imagine how amazing the final product will be.
